DataElement.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Feature Present Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the chronic graft versus host disease gastrointestinal tract feature that was present.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Feature Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation._The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff._A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Feature
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation.:The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.:A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation.

The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Property.preferredDefinition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Feature Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A reaction, which may be fatal, in an immunocompromised subject (host) who has received an antigenically incompatible tissue transplant (graft) from an immunocompetent donor. The reaction is secondary to the activation of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that express an antigen not expressed by the donor, and is seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation; acute disease is seen after 5-40 days, and chronic disease occurs weeks to months after transplantation._The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff._A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

PermissibleValues.value: Esophageal web / proximal stricture or ring
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Esophageal Web And/Or Proximal Esophageal Stricture

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Esophageal Web And/Or Proximal Esophageal Stricture
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin membrane that is present in the esophageal lumen. It is composed of mucosa and submucosa and it may be associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.: Narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.

Concepts.definition: A thin membrane that is present in the esophageal lumen. It is composed of mucosa and submucosa and it may be associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.
Narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical finding indicating less than normal growth in an infant or child, or a state of global decline in an adult.

Concepts.definition: A clinical finding indicating less than normal growth in an infant or child, or a state of global decline in an adult.

PermissibleValues.value: Weight loss greater than or equal to 5 percent
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Greater Than or Equal To Five Percent Unit Weight Loss

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Greater Than or Equal To Five Percent Unit Weight Loss
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.: A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.: A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).: A reduction in total body weight.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.
A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).
A reduction in total body weight.
Watery bowel movements.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth.

Concepts.definition: Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Upper abdominal discomfort associated with an urge to vomit.

Concepts.definition: Upper abdominal discomfort associated with an urge to vomit.
Loss of appetite.

A symptom referring to difficulty in swallowing. It may be observed in patients with stroke, motor neuron disorders, cancer of the throat or mouth, head and neck injuries, Parkinson disease, and multiple sclerosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Feature Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A reaction, which may be fatal, in an immunocompromised subject (host) who has received an antigenically incompatible tissue transplant (graft) from an immunocompetent donor. The reaction is secondary to the activation of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that express an antigen not expressed by the donor, and is seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation; acute disease is seen after 5-40 days, and chronic disease occurs weeks to months after transplantation.:The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.:A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A reaction, which may be fatal, in an immunocompromised subject (host) who has received an antigenically incompatible tissue transplant (graft) from an immunocompetent donor. The reaction is secondary to the activation of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that express an antigen not expressed by the donor, and is seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation; acute disease is seen after 5-40 days, and chronic disease occurs weeks to months after transplantation.

The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
